title: Alzheimer's Disease: Potential Benefit of Isoflavones
description_brief: The purpose of this pilot study is to evaluate the potential effects of soy isoflavone supplements on cognitive function for men and women with Alzheimer's Disease (AD). Preliminary studies evaluating the effects of soy supplements on memory in cognitively healthy older adults have yielded promising results that are now being evaluated in patients with AD. It is hypothesized that isoflavone supplements will ameliorate cognitive declines for older adults diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease, when compared to subjects on placebo.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: 4 subjects withdrew consent; 3 subjects ineligible due to abnormal laboratory tests or inability to complete testing

measures.title: Number of participants with Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE4) allele
measures.description: One subject in each group declined to undergo ApoE genotyping
measures.populationDescription: One subject in each group declined to undergo ApoE genotyping

Global cognition: Mini-Mental State Examination score
Mood symptoms: Geriatric Depression Scale-Short Form score

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Outcomes - Language Executive Function : Category Fluency Assessed as Number of Words Generated/Min
outcomeMeasures.description: Participants are given 1 min to produce as many unique words as possible within a category (category fluency). More words per minute will correlates to better category fluency
outcomeMeasures.unitOfMeasure: number of words generated per minute

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Outcomes - Language Executive Function : Phonemic Fluency/Verbal Fluency Assessed as Number of Words Generated Per Minute
outcomeMeasures.description: Participants are given 1 min to produce as many words as possible starting with a given letter (letter fluency). More number of words per minute correlates to better phonemic fluency/verbal fluency
outcomeMeasures.unitOfMeasure: number of words generated per minute

outcomeMeasures.title: Immediate and Delayed Recall on Verbal Memory/ List Learning Immediate and Delayed Free Recall: Number of Words Recalled
outcomeMeasures.description: List of 15 semantically unrelated words is presented verbally to the participants once, after which they are asked to free recall as many words as possible. Subsequently, this presentation-test routine (learning trials) is repeated four more times. A total recall score is determined by adding the number of recalled items for the five learning trials. After presentation of a distractor list and a delay of approximately 20 minutes, participants are asked to freely recall items from the original word list. A delayed recall score is then derived from this test.

outcomeMeasures.title: Immediate and Delayed Recall on Verbal Memory/ Logical Memory Immediate and Delayed Recall: Number of Story Elements Recalled
outcomeMeasures.description: In the logical delayed memory test, participants are read a logically organized story. Approximately 20 minutes later, the participants are asked to recall the story from memory (Delayed Recall). The version used in this study uses only one story (Story A) read once to participants at each study visit. Possible scores for delayed recall trials range from 0 to 25, with higher scores reflecting more details recalled.

outcomeMeasures.title: Measure of Divided Attention: Time to Complete Trail Making Test B
outcomeMeasures.description:
Trail Making Test-Version B (TMT B) \[113\], a measure of divided attention, the subject is asked to draw lines to connect consecutively numbered and lettered circles, alternating between the 2 sequences. The time needed to complete the task is recorded.

More time taken to complete the test or higher score indicates lower executive function/higher impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: A Test of Planning: Time to Complete Mazes
outcomeMeasures.description: Time to complete mazes is a test of planning. Subjects are asked to complete a set of 3 mazes. The time taken to complete the maze is inversely proportional to the cognitive function.

outcomeMeasures.title: Measure of Selective Attention: Time to Complete Stroop Color Word Test
outcomeMeasures.description:
Selective attention was evaluated with the Stroop Color Word Interference Test. In the interference portion of this test, the subject identifies the color of ink in which words ("red", "green", or "blue") are printed, requiring the subject to inhibit their natural tendency to read the word. A subject's score is the time taken to identify 50 stimulus items.

The time taken to complete the maze is inversely proportional to the cognitive function.

outcomeMeasures.title: Visual Memory Test: Complex Figure Delayed Recall; Number of Points
outcomeMeasures.description: Visual memory will be evaluated by complex figure delayed recall test. In this test , a two dimensional figure is shown to the subjects. After a delay of 30 min, they are asked to draw the same figure based on their memory. The Complex Figure Test assesses the subject's ability to remember a 2-dimensional figure presented briefly. The scoring system used includes scores related to location, accuracy and organization. Higher score correlates to better visual memory.

outcomeMeasures.title: Visual Memory : Benton Visual Retention Test: Number of Correct Figures
outcomeMeasures.description:
The Benton Visual Retention Test (or simply Benton test or BVRT) is an individually administered test for people aged from 8 years to adulthood that measures visual perception and visual memory. It can also be used to help identify possible learning disabilities among other afflictions that might affect an individual's memory. The individual examined is shown 10 designs, one at a time, and asked to reproduce each one as exactly as possible on plain paper from memory. The test is untimed, and the results are professionally scored by form, shape, pattern, and arrangement on the paper.

For the 'test of number of correct figures' score is calculated based on an all-or-nothing approach; points are awarded if the reproduction of the design matches the original.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Outcomes - Visual Memory : Benton Visual Retention; Number of Errors
outcomeMeasures.description:
The Benton Visual Retention Test is an individually administered test for people aged from 8 years to adulthood that measures visual perception and visual memory. It can also be used to help identify possible learning disabilities among other afflictions that might affect an individual's memory. The individual examined is shown 10 designs, one at a time, and asked to reproduce each one as exactly as possible on plain paper from memory. The test is untimed, and the results are professionally scored by form, shape, pattern, and arrangement on the paper.

For the 'test of number of errors' score is calculated based on the number and type of errors made for each design. The major categories for these errors are omissions, distortions, perseverations, rotations, misplacements, and size errors.These scores are then be compared to several sets of normative data available in the manual, each representing different demographic characteristics, and conclusions can be drawn by the examiner.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Outcomes - Visual Motor : Complex Figure Copy; Number of Points
outcomeMeasures.description: Visual memory will be evaluated by Complex Figure copy test. The Complex Figure Test assesses the subject's ability to copy a 2-dimensional figure. The scoring system used include scores related to location, accuracy and organization. Higher score correlates to better visual memory.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Outcomes - Visual Motor : Time to Complete Grooved Pegboard Test Using the Dominant Hand
outcomeMeasures.description: The Grooved Pegboard is a dexterity test consisting of 25 holes with randomly positioned slots. Pegs with a key on one side must be rotated to match the hole before they can be inserted. Participants are instructed to place all pegs into the 25 holes, picking up one at a time, and using just one hand. They use their dominant hand. Time taken to finish the test inversely correlates to the cognitive ability.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Outcomes - Visual Motor : Time to Complete Grooved Pegboard Test Using the Non-Dominant Hand
outcomeMeasures.description: The Grooved Pegboard is a dexterity test consisting of 25 holes with randomly positioned slots. Pegs with a key on one side must be rotated to match the hole before they can be inserted. Participants are instructed to place all pegs into the 25 holes, picking up one at a time, and using just one hand. They use their non-dominant hand. Time taken to finish the test inversely correlates to the cognitive ability.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Outcomes-Global Cognition : Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) Score
outcomeMeasures.description:
During the MMSE, a health professional asks a participant a series of questions designed to test memory, ability to solve simple problems and other thinking skills.

The maximum MMSE score - 30 points. Score of 20 to 24 - mild dementia, 13 to 20 - moderate dementia, and \<12 indicates severe dementia.

On average, the MMSE score of a person with Alzheimer's declines about 2 to 4 points each year.

outcomeMeasures.title: Multiple Mood States: Profile of Mood States (POMS)-Depression Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Depression scale is one of the subscale of POMS. Depression scale has 15 items and scores ranges from 0-60. Higher score indicates more severe depression.

outcomeMeasures.title: Multiple Mood States: Profile of Mood States (POMS)-Tension Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Tension scale is one of the subscale of POMS. Tension scale has 9 items and scores ranges from 0-36. Higher score indicates more severe outcomes.

outcomeMeasures.title: Multiple Mood States: Profile of Mood States (POMS)-Anger Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Anger scale is one of the subscale of POMS. Tension scale has 12 items and scores ranges from 0-48. Higher score indicates more anger issues.

outcomeMeasures.title: Multiple Mood States: Profile of Mood States (POMS)-Fatigue Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Fatigue scale is one of the subscale of POMS. Tension scale has 7 items and scores ranges from 0-28. Higher score indicates more fatigue.

outcomeMeasures.title: Multiple Mood States: Profile of Mood States (POMS)-Vigor Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Vigor scale is one of the subscale of POMS. Vigor scale has 8 items and scores ranges from 0-32. Higher score indicates more severe outcomes.

outcomeMeasures.title: Multiple Mood States: Profile of Mood States (POMS)-Confusion Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Confusion scale is one of the subscale of POMS. Confusion scale has 7 items and scores ranges from 0-28. Higher score indicates more severe outcomes.

outcomeMeasures.title: Geriatric Depression Scale-Subject Report
outcomeMeasures.description:
Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS) has been tested and used extensively with the older population to measure depression.

Subject will self-report a short form GDS consisting of 15 questions. Out of 15 items, 10 indicate the presence of depression when answered positively, while the rest (question numbers 1, 5, 7, 11, 13) indicate depression when answered negatively.

Scores of 0-4 are considered normal, depending on age, education, and complaints; Scores of 5-8 indicate mild depression; 9-11 indicate moderate depression; and Scores of 12-15 indicate severe depression.

The Short Form is more easily used by physically ill and mildly to moderately demented patients who have short attention spans and/or feel easily fatigued. It takes about 5 to 7 minutes to complete

outcomeMeasures.title: Geriatric Depression Scale-Study Partner Report
outcomeMeasures.description:
Study partner is someone who has frequent contact with the subject (e.g. an average of 10 hours per week or more), and can accompany the subject to all clinic visits for the duration of the protocol.

Study partner will report a short form GDS consisting of 15 questions. Out of 15 items, 10 indicate the presence of depression when answered positively, while the rest (question numbers 1, 5, 7, 11, 13) indicate depression when answered negatively.

Scores of 0-4 are considered normal, depending on age, education, and complaints; Scores of 5-8 indicate mild depression; 9-11 indicate moderate depression; and Scores of 12-15 indicate severe depression.

The Short Form is more easily used by physically ill and mildly to moderately demented patients who have short attention spans and/or feel easily fatigued. It takes about 5 to 7 minutes to complete.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants With ApoE4 Allele
outcomeMeasures.description:
The epsilon-4 allele of the apolipoprotein E gene (APOE4) has been consistently associated with a greater risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD) as well as an earlier onset of AD.

Determination of apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype was performed on a non-fasting blood sample collected at Baseline, using standard Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and DNA sequencing techniques in a Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) certified laboratory. DNA extracted from whole blood was amplified by PCR using specific primers for the ApoE gene and the DNA then sequenced and analyzed for genotype using the FinchTV program (Version 1.3; Geospiza, Inc.)

outcomeMeasures.title: Plasma Concentrations of Isoflavones at Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description:
Isoflavone assays will be performed on non-fasting blood samples collected at baseline.

Novasoy capsules predominantly contain purified glycoside forms of isoflavones known genistein and diadzein. The plasma level of genistein and diadzine will be measured in the participants plasma.There is large inter-individual variations in the extent of intestinal metabolism, even when the quantity of isoflavone intake is standardized. Equol is a metabolite of isoflavones. Equol has high biological efficacy. Therefore, along with genistein and diadzein, plasma levels of equol will be measured to understand the isoflavone metabolism in the participants.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data is unavailable for 2 subject from placebo group and 1 subjects from Novasoy group

outcomeMeasures.title: Plasma Concentrations of Isoflavones at Month 3
outcomeMeasures.description:
Isoflavone assays will be performed on non-fasting blood samples collected at month 3.

Novasoy capsules predominantly contain purified glycoside forms of isoflavones known genistein and diadzein. The plasma level of genistein and diadzine will be measured in the participants plasma.There is large inter-individual variations in the extent of intestinal metabolism, even when the quantity of isoflavone intake is standardized. Equol is a metabolite of isoflavones. Equol has high biological efficacy. Therefore, along with genistein and diadzein, plasma levels of equol will be measured to understand the isoflavone metabolism in the participants.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data is unavailable for 1 subject from each group

outcomeMeasures.title: Plasma Concentrations of Isoflavones at Month 6
outcomeMeasures.description:
Isoflavone assays will be performed on non-fasting blood samples collected at month 6.

Novasoy capsules predominantly contain purified glycoside forms of isoflavones known genistein and diadzein. The plasma level of genistein and diadzine will be measured in the participants plasma.There is large inter-individual variations in the extent of intestinal metabolism, even when the quantity of isoflavone intake is standardized. Equol is a metabolite of isoflavones. Equol has high biological efficacy. Therefore, along with genistein and diadzein, plasma levels of equol will be measured to understand the isoflavone metabolism in the participants.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data is unavailable for 1 subject from placebo group and 3 subjects from Novasoy group

outcomeMeasures.title: Plasma Concentrations of Estradiol at Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description: Estradiol assay will be performed on non-fasting blood samples collected at baseline using an enzyme immunoassay kit.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Estradiol analysis done by the same investigator as part of another project with different subjects (PMID: 9054783 linked in the citation), did not show any change in the estradiol levels. Based on that, investigators did not see the justification for running these analyses in the current study. No estradiol analyses were performed for this study.

outcomeMeasures.description: Estradiol assay will be performed on non-fasting blood samples collected at baseline using an enzyme immunoassay kit.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Estradiol analysis done by the same investigator as part of another project with different subjects (PMID: 9054783 linked in the citation), did not show any change in the estradiol levels. Based on that, investigators did not see the justification for running these analyses in the current study. No estradiol analyses were performed for this study.

Based on that, investigators did not see the justification for running these analyses in the current study. No estradiol analyses were performed for this study.

seriousEvents.notes: Death due to complications from Alzheimer's disease

otherEvents.term: other illness not related to treatment

drug: soy isoflavone supplements (primarily genistein and daidzein; metabolite equol)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial description tests oral soy isoflavone supplements to "ameliorate cognitive declines" in people with Alzheimer's disease, so the intended effect is improvement of cognition rather than a biologic (e.g., antibody) that targets core Alzheimer pathology (amyloid/tau). This fits the "Cognitive enhancer" category by the provided definitions.

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: soy isoflavone supplements (100 mg/day in the pilot described in the literature); common constituents are genistein and daidzein (and the metabolite equol), and the comparator was matching placebo capsules. Clinical trial reports of this intervention in AD and older adults exist (pilot RCT in AD; other RCTs/meta-analyses of cognitive outcomes). citeturn0search7turn0search8turn0search4

Evidence from the literature: a randomized pilot trial of 100 mg/day soy isoflavones in older adults with AD found no overall cognitive benefit versus placebo after 6 months, though exploratory analyses linked equol levels to some cognitive measures. Meta-analyses of RCTs in older adults report small improvements in overall cognition and memory with soy isoflavones. These sources show the intervention is a dietary small-molecule phytoestrogen tested for cognitive effects rather than a disease-modifying biologic. citeturn0search7turn0search4turn0search1

Reflect: Classification confirmed — soy isoflavones are plant-derived small molecules (phytoestrogens) intended here to improve cognitive performance/symptoms; they are not monoclonal antibodies/vaccines (biologics) nor described as directly targeting amyloid or tau pathology. Some uncertainty remains about effect size and responders (e.g., equol producers), but that does not change the category. citeturn0search4turn0search7
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests oral soy isoflavone supplements (genistein, daidzein, metabolite equol) to improve cognition in people with Alzheimer’s disease — a symptomatic/cognitive-enhancing approach rather than a disease-modifying therapy directed at amyloid or tau. This is described in the randomized AD trial and pilot RCTs. citeturn0search3turn0search4

Act: Key extracted details and mechanism: intervention = soy isoflavone supplements (commonly 100 mg/day in trials); principal constituents = genistein and daidzein, with equol as an active metabolite. Isoflavones are plant-derived phytoestrogens that preferentially bind estrogen receptors (notably ERβ) and have antioxidant and neuroprotective effects in preclinical models — mechanisms consistent with modulation of synaptic plasticity and neuroprotection rather than targeting amyloid/tau directly. Clinical RCT evidence in AD and older adults shows mixed/small symptomatic effects but does not support a disease-modifying anti-amyloid or anti-tau action. citeturn0search4turn0search5turn0search7

Reflect: CADRO mapping — the most specific CADRO category matching a symptomatic cognitive enhancer / neuroprotective small molecule (phytoestrogen) is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. Although isoflavones act via hormone receptors (phytoestrogen/ER interaction), the trial intent (improve cognition/neuroprotection) and mechanisms (synaptic modulation, antioxidant/neuroprotective effects) align better with M than with L (Growth Factors & Hormones), which is typically used for classical endocrine/growth-factor interventions. The AD trials cited describe symptomatic cognitive endpoints rather than direct targeting of core AD proteinopathies (amyloid/tau). citeturn0search3turn0search7

Web search results (key sources used): 1) "Cognitive Effects of Soy Isoflavones in Patients with Alzheimer’s Disease" (RCT, PMC). citeturn0search3 2) "A preliminary study of the safety, feasibility and cognitive efficacy of soy isoflavone supplements in older men and women" (pilot RCT, PMC). citeturn0search4 3) Review/preclinical evidence on genistein/daidzein neuroprotection and ERβ affinity (physiology journal). citeturn0search5 4) Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation summary on soy isoflavones (clinical evidence & interpretation). citeturn0search7
